stem: Complete the emergency protocol for a client with a T6 spinal cord injury reporting a severe headache.
template: A client with T6 injury and BP 210/110 should first be {{positioning}}. The nurse should then assess for the most common cause, which is {{cause}}.

options: kept flat in a supine position

rationale.correct: Autonomic dysreflexia is a hypertensive crisis. (1) Sitting the client up uses gravity to lower intracranial pressure and blood pressure. (2) The trigger is usually a noxious stimulus below the level of injury, most commonly a full bladder.
rationale.incorrect: Trendelenburg would increase blood pressure in the head, potentially causing a stroke.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 1
answerBreakdown.content: The selection of "placed in a high-Fowler's position" correctly completes the clinical hypothesis based on assessment cues.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 2
answerBreakdown.content: The selection of "bladder distention or fecal impaction" correctly completes the clinical hypothesis based on assessment cues.

clinicalPearls: Other signs of AD include flushing/sweating ABOVE the level of injury and pale/cool skin BELOW the level of injury.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Always 'Position' before 'Medication' in AD. If the BP is still high after sitting up and emptying the bladder, then consider Hydralazine or Nitropaste.

mnemonic.title: U-P
mnemonic.expansion: Up (Head of Bed), Under (Check for kinks/full bladder).

reviewUnits.heading: Spinal Cord Injury Complications
reviewUnits.body: Nurses educate clients on bowel/bladder regimens to prevent AD. It occurs in injuries at or above T6.
